Bennedict

i had a lecture in chemistry today, and something occurred to me about this forum - why dont ID supporters ever complain about chemistry? you know the argument, 'evolution is bad science because we cant actually see it happening, and science is all about observable evidence...' well, almost everything in chemistry relies on atomic theory which has never been observed. research and testing, logical reasoning developed the atomic theory, and its a pretty good one at that. evolution is the same deal, but maybe even more convincing, since it has been observed.
 
 i always thought i knew the answer to "why do creationists pick on biology and not the other sciences?" i thought its because it deals with the touchy subject of life and how we came to be, which seems to contradict the biblical story of creation. but after thinking it through, im not so sure anymore. atomic theory is an even weaker theory (still strong, but slightly weaker in comparison to evolution, imo) that explains so much, yet it remains untouched. if ID proponents have a problem with evolution due to a lack of observable evidence, they must have loads to say about atomic theory. but they dont, and that leaves me with the original question, why do creationists pick on biology? chemistry sucks. i wish the creationists would attack that area of science so i wouldnt have to take a million chemistry classes.
 
 thinking about it now, physics and especially astronomy are very much contradictions of the biblical creation story. we have learned that the earth is not special other than its ability to support life, there are planets like it that can support life, even our closest neighbor planet is thought to have once supported life. this again is unobserved evidence and like everything in science, always questionable. however, it isnt astrophysics or atomic theory the creationists are after, its EVOLUTION... but why? pick on Gilbert Lewis or beat up Stephen Hawking.

 OK, so that was your best one. Here we go:
 
 The Hebrew Bible nowhere states that the earth, plants and daytime were created before the sun. A careful reading of the primary Hebrew text (as opposed to our English translations which often reflect certain sectarian biases) reveals that the sun, moon and stars were all present in Genesis 1:1-3: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. Now the earth was deserted and empty and darkness was on the surface of the ocean, And the Spirit of God was brooding over the waters. Then God said, Let there be light ... There was evening and there was morning - day one" (literal translation of the Masoretic text). 
 
 It must always be remembered that the description of creation is from a geocentric point-of-view, i.e. an observer on the earth. The writer of Genesis is not standing in space looking down on earth. That juxtaposition is critical. 
 
 We continue: 
 
 "And God said, Let luminaries in the expanse of the air be for separating the day from the night. And let them serve as signals to mark seasons and days and years. And let them be luminaries in the expanse of the air to give light upon the earth. And it was so. God brought forth (not 'created' or 'made') two great luminaries - the greater luminary to dominate the day and the lesser luminary to dominate the night - the stars also. God gave them forth in the expanse of the air ... " (Gen.1:14-16, literal translation). 
 
 The point will become clear as we examine the literal words of two other passages: 
 
 "Where were you when I laid the earth's foundation? ... Who shut up the sea behind doors when it burst forth from the womb, when I made the clouds its garment and thick darkness a diaper for it ... ?" (Job 38:4,8-9). "For six days Yahweh worked on the air and the land, the sea and all that is in them ..." (Ex.20:11) 
 
 In other words, the sun and moon and stars were all present from the beginning but were not initially visible from the earth's surface until the third day when the thick layer of water-saturated cloud was dispersed. 
 
 NCCG.ORG New Covenant Church of God - B'rit Chadashah Assembly of Yahweh, FAQ 325: When was the Sun Created?
 
 Also, have you ever read Revelation 21:23? 
 
 "The city does not need the sun or the moon to shine on it, for the glory of God gives it light, and the Lamb is its lamp." So, the initial "light" can arguably be the light of God. Or it can simply be light appearing somewhere in the universe.
 
 Your objection fails, or at best is inconclusive.

Bennedict

Show me why I should have a problem with chemistry? Robert Boyle is considered the Father of Chemistry and he believed in God. You knew that, right?
 
 50 Nobel Laureates and Other Great Scientists Who Believe in God

 
 he absolutely was. however, ill mention 3 chemists that developed the atomic theory (Boyle didnt), and compare it to the theory of evolution.
 Bohr, Thompson and Rutherford (who worked at my university!)
 
 Bohr could be considered the "Darwin" of atomic theory. his theory was correct, but he was off on his details - and he would have been because of the technology he had at the time, just like Darwin.
 
 atomic theory has been modified a lot, mainly by Thompson and Rutherford, but Bohr's original theory and hypothesis are still very much true - much like Darwin's. however, the difference lies in the fact that atomic theory has NOT been proven, whereas evolution has been, many times. i dont want to repeat every other thread in this forum by listing off the massive amount of conclusive evidence to support evolution, all i want to do is ask, why is atomic theory not under attack? its lacking more conclusive evidence than evolution, its relied heavily on by chemists, and its never once been directly observered.
 
 why should you have a problem with chemistry? why should you have a problem with biology? to you, they should both be equally unjustified, yet you choose the stronger one to pick at, and leave the weaker one alone. if finding proof for an accepted theory is so important to you, why not have a problem with atomic theory?

 yes, that is the creationist viewpoint. however, ID supporters try their best to distance themselves from the more primative "creationist" title, and they do that by having actual scientists (well, just one actually: Behe) use scientific arguments to try and dismantle evolution. this of course fails terribly, but still, the idea that biological creationism has now bled into the scientific community begs the question, why do they target evolution only? under the principles argued by ID supporters, they should be attacking nearly every scientific theory out there. ID advocates claim they are entirely science based, with no affiliation to religion, no? we all know this is a lie, but they are still making the claim. then they go and attack evolution because of a so called lack of evidence. if they are honestly science based with no affiliation to religion, they MUST have a problem with atomic theory.
 
 not doing so is a return to biological creationism pre-ID.
